instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PWRBTN_L: What is PWRBTN_L? PWRBTN_L Is an abbreviation of PM_PWRBTN_L which refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
hello i have <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> when i recieved <TRANSISTOR>Q7310</TRANSISTOR> is over heating so i decided to replace it (no more overheating <TRANSISTOR>Q7310</TRANSISTOR>) 
but still cant on i have orange light no fan spin. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.6V pin 1 2
and i just notice F4800 0.0V with 0.0000 diode to ground. 

<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is missing.
removed <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> still missing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Do you have 3V at <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>?
It should drop to 0V when trigger it; just temporar contact to ground, like 1s.
You must check <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> reaction at the same time.

And PLEASE, write the signal names correctly!

yes got 3.4v  at <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> 
when triggering it drops to 0V
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> voltage drops as well when triggering  <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Try to post ALWAYS accurate information.
If not, the help can be useless; as it is based on your replies!

If <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> reacts, then check for pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> (at the same time, of course).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
OK, check if <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> have the same reaction.

Also try turning on in SMC bypass mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> have the same reaction? yes it is.
from 0.0V up to 3.2v when triggering  <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>

smc bypass mode failed. (no reaction)

lets go back to my original post.

i mentioned that the  <TRANSISTOR>Q7310</TRANSISTOR> is overheating.
now i tried removed again the  <TRANSISTOR>Q7310</TRANSISTOR> chip and i test  (diode to ground <TRANSISTOR>Q7310</TRANSISTOR> from board pin 1 2 3 <SIGNAL>CPUVR_PHASE1</SIGNAL> is 0.0001
compare to working board it was 0.0053 what does it mean? is it cpu short circuit? is this the real problem?  
is there something that i can still do to solve the issue?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
I don't think <TRANSISTOR>Q7310</TRANSISTOR> is bad; you've said to have short on board WITHOUT it soldered.
If was shorted, no way to get <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> also.

<TRANSISTOR>Q7311</TRANSISTOR> can generate short to ground.
Remove L7310 and check where the short remains.
If will remain on <RESISTOR>R7310</RESISTOR>, very likely CPU is fried...
